question: B 04 (b)
sols_html:
The columns of a linear transformation matrix, A, are populated by the transformed vectors of each of the basis vectors. In this case the first column of A will be \([1,0,0]\times\mathbf{a}\), the second, \([0,1,0]\times\mathbf{a}\), and the third, \([0,0,1]\times\mathbf{a}\). By computing these cross products, we get,

\[\begin{aligned} \left[1,0,0\right]\times\mathbf{a}=[1,2,-1]&=[0,1,2]\\ \left[0,1,0\right]\times\mathbf{a}=[1,2,-1]&=[-1,0,-1]\\ \left[0,0,1\right]\times\mathbf{a}=[1,2,-1]&=[-2,1,0]\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the linear transformation matrix A which corresponds to T is,

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & -2\\ 1 & 0 & 1\\ 2 & -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Notice if we wanted some sort of confirmation of our answer we can pick a random vector, say x=[3,4,7], compute \(\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}\) and compute Ax and make sure they are the same thing.

\[\begin{aligned} [3,4,7]\times[1,2,-1]=[-18,10,2]\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} A \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -18\\ 10\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which is indeed the same result.

statement_html:
Let a=[1,2,-1]. Consider the transformation \(T:\mathbb{R}^3\to\mathbb{R}^3\) defined by \(T(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{x}\times\mathbf{a}\) for all x in \(\mathbb{R}^3\), where \(\times\) is the cross-product in \(\mathbb{R}^3\).

Find the matrix A that corresponds to T.
